Fig. 1 TPR-H2 curves per mg sample for: 1) Ga(NO3)3/SiO2 after 0.5 h in air at 80 °C, 2) Ga(NO3)3 after 1 h in air at 600 °C, 3) Ga(NO3)3 after 3 h in air at 600 °C, 4) Ga(NO3)3/SiO2 after 1 h in air at 600 °C 5) Silica- SiO2. Fig 1 Fig. 2 TPR-H2 curves per mg Ga after 8 h in air at 600 °C for: 1) Ga2O3; 2) Ga(2 %)/SiO2; 3) Ga(3 %)/ SiO2; 4) Ga(5 %)/SiO2; 5) Ga(10 %)/SiO2. Fig 2 Fig. 3 XRD pattern of: (1) mechanical mixture Ga2O3:Silica=10:90; (2) Ga(5 %)/SiO2-used; (3) Ga(10 %)/SiO2-fresh. Fig 3 Fig. 4 The electron microscopy data for the Ga(5 %)/SiO2 sample: EDS-maps for the same area of Si location (A) and Ga location (B); BF-STEM image (C). Fig 4 Fig. 5 TPD-NH3 curves for samples: 1) from 25 °C for Silica; 2) from 25 °C for Ga(2 %)/SiO2; 3) from 110 °C for Ga(2 %)/SiO2. The present work is devoted to the studies of Ga/Silica catalysts in the paraffins dehydrogenation of natural gas - propane and ethane to produce valuable products - olefins and hydrogen. The gallium oxide supported on silica gel (2–10 %wt. of Ga) have been studied using XRD, TPR-H2 and STEM/EDS methods, it has been shown that the dispersion of gallium oxide over the silica surface is very effective, the support actively reacts with a gallium salt to form surface particles that are more easily reduced than pure gallium oxide. Under steady and no-stationary state the negative effect of oxidative pre-treatment and the addition of CO2 to the reaction mixture on catalytic activity was detected. On the contrary, pre-treatment of the catalysts in hydrogen (at 650–700 °C) or CO addition to the reaction mixture was accompanied by an increase in their propane dehydrogenation activities and stabilities at 600 °C. In the ethane dehydrogenation conditions (650 to 700 °C) catalysts is effective treated by hydrogen during the experiment. At 700 °C, the Ga/Silica activity may even increase during ethane dehydrogenation. By TPR-H2 it was observed that with an increase in the temperature of pre-treatment of Ga/Silica in hydrogen from 650 to 700 °C, the proportion of oxidized Ga-containing phase significantly decreases. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Light alkanes dehydrogenation Gallium catalysts Catalysts activation Natural gas conversion Gallium on silica supported Mechanism of dehydrogenation Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Efficient processing of natural gas paraffins is the most important area of modern chemistry. The main processes of this direction are thermal[1,2] and catalytic[3,4] cracking, isomerization[5,6], cyclization (aromatization)[7-9] and dehydrogenation[10-29,35-39]. Olefins and hydrogen are among the most useful types of raw materials today, especially given the spread of hydrogen energy. In this regard, interest in the process in which olefins and hydrogen are simultaneously formed from cheap natural gas - dehydrogenation of light paraffins - is steadily growing. The supported Pt- and Cr-containing catalysts exhibit high activity in the dehydrogenation of light alkanes and are the main ones for industrial realization[10,11]. Over the years, more and more interest has arisen not only in the possibility of creating more productive catalysts, but also in the possibility of replacing existing systems with inexpensive catalysts that are resistant to high temperatures, coke deposits, residual impurities accompanying natural gas and have low toxicity. One of the problems of dehydrogenation catalysts connected with the coke deposition. Catalysts base on Cr, Ni, V etc. require regeneration, which can be carried out either by intermediate regeneration (the periodical changing the reactor or carrying out cyclic transfer of the catalyst to the zone of coke oxidation) or by introducing oxidizing agents into the reaction mixture (O2[12,13], CO2[14,15], N2O[16] etc.). In the last case an obvious disadvantage is the loss of a valuable product - hydrogen. For Pt-catalysts, the decrease of coking can be achieved by introducing hydrogen[10]. Another problem is the stability of the active phase and the structure of the support. To solve the second problem, a careful selection of the support, active phase, modifying additives and preparation conditions is necessary[10,11,15,17]. However, researchers around the world are looking not only for ways to improve existing catalysts, but also for ways to replace them. Gallium systems based on zeolites have long been known for their effectiveness in the aromatization reactions of light paraffins, which include the dehydrogenation stage[9]. In relation to the dehydrogenation of paraffins, gallium catalysts have been studied relatively recently. These systems are less active than catalysts based on chromium or platinum, but they are characterized by high selectivity and stability[18-22]. The authors of[23-26] suggest that the mechanism of dehydrogenation on gallium catalysts includes the stages of formation of gallium hydrides and alcoholates, which, when destroyed, form dehydrogenation products. Therefore, an important role in the dehydrogenation of paraffins on gallium catalysts can be played by the degree of oxidation of the active surface, which depends on the pretreatment conditions (during oxidation with oxygen or reduction with hydrogen) and the composition of the reaction mixture (for example, when carbon oxides CO and CO2 are introduced). However, the results of the studies given in the literature demonstrate an ambiguous result of the pretreatment of gallium systems. In[27], the authors showed that the efficiency of the Ga2O3:Al2O3 mixed oxides in the dehydrogenation of propane in the presence of CO2 depends on the Ga: Al ratio, the catalyst works stably at a ratio of 4:1, while the concentration of CO2 does not vary. The authors[28] studied the Ga/HZSM-5 catalyst for propane dehydrogenation and suggested that the conversion of propane occurs at centers including monovalent Ga+ cations. In the paper[29], the authors show the positive effect of reducing treatment of Ga/SiO2 catalysts on the yield of olefins during propane dehydrogenation, while the support is a porous material with a developed surface (410 м2/г). In the work[30], the formation of a bond Gaδ+-H is shown with the help of FTIR, the presence of which is fixed already at 450 °C in the presence of hydrogen on the surface of Ga/SiO2. In addition, in[31], the authors showed that high-temperature reduction treatment of SiO2 at 600–1000 °C leads to the destruction of the Si-Si bond with the formation of a Si-H bond. The IR-investigation for reduce in H2 Ga/HZSM5 catalysts present at next works[32,33]. Spectra's show the presence of intense peaks at wavenumbers 2040 cm-1. The peak has been reported to correspond to the Ga-H bond stretching vibration. In addition, in the work[34] by FTIR is observed the formation of several different types of Ga-H species such as Ga-H bond formed on tetrahedral Ga (2003 cm-1) and octahedral Ga (1980 cm-1). At works[35,36] autors have performed reduction treatments on Ga2O3/SiO2 catalysts and have characterized the samples using XPS. They have also observed the formation of an low binding energy Ga peak in the Ga3d region for the reduced samples. The peak is observed at a binding energy of 19.6 eV and can similarly be assigned to Ga+δ, where 0<δ< 3[30,35]. In this contex, the results obtained for systems GaOx using TPR-H2[37] are interesting. The authors show that for pure Ga2O3 exhibits two reduction peaks, centered close to 507 °C and 771 °C, which are ascribed to small Ga2O3 particles and segregated bulk Ga2O3, respectively. The authors conclude based on the literature data that these peaks of hydrogen absorption correspond to transitions from Ga(3+) to Ga(1+), changes that occur in reducing conditions paraffins dehydrogenation. In another paper[18], studies of TPR-H2 were carried out for different forms of gallium oxide (α, β, γ, δ). The authors logically note that very small peaks of hydrogen absorption are detected for different forms of gallium oxides, and the first one appears at temperatures in the range of 200–300 °C and only for the δ-form there is another peak of about 370 °C. These results obviously differ from the data obtained in the previous work[37], while it should be noted that the authors of the work[19] find an interesting effect: after the work of gallium oxide in the dehydrogenation of propane and re-oxidation in oxygen, the peaks of hydrogen absorption at TPR-H2 do not appear at all. In addition, in the latest work, the authors are interested in the effect of pretreatment of gallium systems and show that pretreatment in hydrogen at 500 °C (compared with oxidative treatment) leads to a decrease in the activity and even selectivity of catalysts during dehydrogenation of propane in the presence of CO2 In another work[38], the authors synthesized nanoparticle catalysts by the colloidal method that differs in the relative ratio of β- and γ-Ga2O3. These samples were studied in detail by various methods and it was shown that its efficiency in the dehydrogenation of propane increases after treatment in hydrogen at 500 °C. The authors explain the effect by an increase in the proportion of β-Ga2O3, which leads to an increase in the content of weak Lewis centers. The effect of carbon dioxide on the work of pure oxides is shown to be very negative, and the authors find the same effect for pure chromium oxide. The course of reasoning in the work also leads to the mechanism of dehydrogenation, including the stage of formation of the Ga-H bond. A detailed review of Ga-containing catalysts deposited on various supports and methods of their preparation is given in[39]. The authors demonstrate the great interest of researchers in various gallium catalysts for dehydrogenation and aromatization of paraffins, as well as cracking and isomerization. The article also shows that researchers have discrepancies in the description of the nature of active centers. The review provides some current limitations and future perspectives for the development of gallium-based catalysts. Thus, the results reported in the literature for gallium-containing catalysts of light paraffin dehydrogenation do not always make it possible to draw strict conclusions about the influence of pretreatment and process conditions on the efficiency of olefin production. There is no doubt that these issues, as well as the study of adsorption and redox properties, require more extensive and detailed research. This work is devoted precisely to this. 2 Experimental The objects of the study were samples of catalysts GaOx/Silica (Ga/Silica) containing 2–10 wt.% of gallium deposited on silica gel. A support pre-calcined at 600 °C was placed in an aqueous solution of gallium nitrate nanohydrate (Ga(NO3)*8H2O, 99.8 %). Then they were kept for 4 h at room temperature and periodically stirring. The method of precipitation of gallium nitrate from aqueous solutions was used to supporting of active phase. At the final stage of preparation, as well as during regeneration, the catalysts were treated in an air current at 600 °C for 8 h. Silica (SiO2) – Silica gel type of KSKG (330–350 m2/g) was used as a support. Tests of the activity of catalysts in propane (600 °C) and ethane (650–700 C°) dehydrogenation were carried out in a flow installation at atmospheric pressure and space velocity 200 - 2000 h-1. Reaction mixtures of different compositions were used in the studies, the propane and ethane initial concentrations for all experiment are 15 %vol. The reaction products were analyzed chromatographically using two columns -molecular sieve 5А (Н2, N2 CH4, CO) and Pоrapak-Q (CO2, hydrocarbons С1-С3, Н2О). The product selectivity and paraffin conversion parameters were calculated using the equations given in[40]. The derivatives of these parameters are the yields and rates of production of olefins. Studies using the non-stationary response method were carried out in a flow system containing 3 independent lines. The catalytic flow system with quartz reactor was connected to an MSKh-6 time-of-flight mass spectrometer, which made it possible to analyze the reaction mixture directly during relatively fast relaxation processes. The conditions for the process ensured that it proceeded in the differential reactor mode. Relaxation curves fixed the processes of a system's transition to a new stationary state in response to a fast change in the concentration of one or more components of the reaction mixture. The main part of the relaxation curves was obtained at 600 °C. In addition, experiments were also carried out on the displacement of helium and carbon dioxide by propylene at 200 °C. The partial pressures of C3H8, C3H6 and CO2 were 0.15 atm, 0.10 atm. and 0.30 atm., respectively. The following mass numbers were measured: 15 (methane), 29 (propane), 41 (propylene), 44 (carbon dioxide). The experiments were carried out on a catalyst containing 10.0 wt.% gallium. In each experiment, only one substance was measured with a periodicity of 0.1 s, which allows us to consider the relaxation curves almost continuous. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected using a Philips PW 1850 powder diffractometer (Co Kα radiation, 40 kV with 20 mA current) and indexed by using Philips X'pert High score software. Hitachi Regulus 8230 field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) was used for microscopic studies. Images were acquired in backscattered electron mode (BF-STEM) at a 30 kV accelerating voltage. The analysis of the catalysts composition was carried out by the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS-SEM) method using the Bruker Quantax 400 EDS system equipped with XFlash 6|60 detector at a 30 kV accelerating voltage. Target-oriented approach was utilized for the optimization of the analytic measurements[41]. The catalyst surface was determined by the BET method, and porosity was measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 instrument. The samples were pretreated in helium flow 2 h at 300 °С. The TPR-H2 and TPD-NH3 data were obtained on a flow installation equipped with a linear sample heating system connected to a TCD detector. Before the TPR measurements, the samples were processed in a dry helium current at 300 °C for 2 hours. A mixture of H2:Ar = 10:90 (% vol.) was used to TPR-experiments, the flow rate of the mixture was 2 l/h, the heating rate was 10–20 °/min. Before TPD-NH3, catalyst samples were treated in a flow of dry He for 2 h at T = 600 °C, after which ammonia was adsorbed from a mixture with argon ([NH3] = 10 % vol.) at a temperature of 30 °C for 20 min and purged with dry helium at the starting temperature (25 or 110 °C) for 30 min. Desorption was carried out into a dry helium flow (2 l/h) with linear heating at a speed of 10 °/min. The ammonia was dried from water using an alumina trap. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalysts characterizations The data obtained by the BET method for silica gel and supported catalysts are presented in Table 1 . It is seen that an increase in the gallium content of the Ga/Silica catalyst result in decreases in the surface area and pore volume. At the same time, the surface size changes monotonically while maintaining the average pore size, without destroying the structure of the support. The formation of the active surface was studied by TPR-H2 method (Fig. 1 ) First, a sample with gallium content of 5 % wt. was reduced immediately after gallium nitrate deposition on Silica gel and air drying at 80 °С (curve 1). It can be seen that three peaks are present in the temperature range 200 -600 °С, which are probably related to the reduction of nitrate ions to NO2, NO and N2. The degree of decomposition-reduction of nitrate from the time of hydrogen treatment can be traced by a wide peak of about 500 °C, which is observed on curves 1, 2 and 3. The results of TPR-H2 for gallium nitrate, which was treated in air at 600 °C for 1 h (curve 2) and 3 h (curve 3) indicate that gallium nitrate at high temperatures slowly decomposes to gallium oxide. Gallium nitrate supported on silica gel decomposes much faster, after 1 h in air at 600 °C, the peaks of hydrogen uptake at TPR-H2 below to 600 °C practically disappear (curve 4), a peak appears with temperature of maximum about 870–890 °C. This peak corresponds to the hydrogen-reduction of oxide particles containing gallium, which is bound to the SiO2 because during the reduction of Silica (Fig. 1, curve 5) and gallium oxide (Fig. 2 , curve 1) the pronounced hydrogen uptake is not detected up to 970 °С. The results indicate that during the synthesis of catalysts, active interaction is carried out between gallium compounds and silica gel. The prepared catalysts, as well as the sample obtained by decomposition of gallium nitrate in air for 1 h, have a large peak with a maximum at 885 °С for Ga(5 %)/Silica (Fig. 2 curve 2) and with a maximum at 914 °С for Ga(10 %)/Silica (Fig. 2 curve 3) at TPR-H2. That is, as the gallium content increases, the specific uptake of hydrogen per mg of gallium decreases. The reason for this may be a decrease in the availability of gallium-contained oxide particles for interaction with hydrogen. This may be due to the enlargement of the active phase particles. Diffractograms of all samples show a wide peak in the region of 14–28 ° (2ϴ) centered at about 22 ° (2ϴ), which belongs to amorphous silica gel structures. XRD pattern of mechanical mixture Ga2O3:Silica (Fig. 3 -1) include the peaks belong to the monoclinic Ga2O3 core (ICDD-PDF #41–1103). In the absence of bond of gallium oxide to the surface of the support, a sample can be obtained with such an X-ray pattern. The results obtained for the catalysts (Fig. 3-2 and Fig. 3-3) indicate that the dispersion of gallium oxide over the support surface is very effective at supporting of active phase. With a Ga content of 5 %wt. (Fig. 3-2), no peaks of crystalline phase were found even for a sample that worked for about 20 h at 650–700 °C temperatures and underwent three stages of intermediate regeneration in oxygen at 600 °C. Only with a gallium content of 10 %wt. can weakly broad characteristic lines of about 30–35 ° and 63–67 ° phases of Ga2O3 be found (Fig. 3-3). If we compare with similar catalysts for precipitation of the oxide-chromium phase on silica gel in our work[15], then in CrOx/Silica diffractograms already at a chromium content of 3 %wt. peaks of chromates crystal structure are detected, and at a content of 5 % wt. these peaks become strong and well resolved, indicating weak dispersity of the active phase. Strong bonding of gallium oxide to the silicate support was also found in work[42]. The authors showed that in composites of Ga2O3:SiO2 obtained by single-step synthesis, the average size of oxide-gallium particles is about 3.5 nm and it is saved at 900 °C. The EDS-maps of Si and Ga locations for the same area of Ga(5)/SiO2 are shown in Fig. 4 A and 4B, respectively. These results indicate a uniform and dispersed deposition of titanum on the silicate support even when the metal content is high. The result from Fig. 4C confirms the high dispersion of gallium and shows that the average size of Ga-containing particles is about 7–9 nm. As the Ga content (10 %wt.) the average size of Ga-containing particles ∼12–16 nm, ∼5–7 nm for Ga(3)/Silica and ∼3–5 nm for Ga(2)/Silica. (Table 1) This result indicates a decrease in Ga-dispersion and, accordingly, an increase in the size of oxidized Ga-containing particles with an increase in gallium content. Next, the acidity of the catalysts studied, determined by TPD-NH3 (Table 1). If the desorption of ammonia from 25 °C is carried out, the differences between the catalysts have little or no trend because the acidity error is large. At the same time, the total acidity of the support is higher than at of the catalysts. Apparently, the active phase replaces a significant portion of the hydroxyls on the SiO2-surface, which are acidic centers. If the TPD of ammonia is carried out after blowing with dry helium at 110 °C, the amount of ammonia will be greatly decrease and only the firmly bound ammonia will remain. In this case, a trend of slightly increasing acidity with increasing gallium content can be observed. Fig. 5 shows the TPD-NH3 curves of the Silica and the catalyst Ga(2 %)Ox/SiO2. It can be seen that above after 290 °C there is practically no ammonia on silica gel anymore. At the same time on the catalyst ammonia desorption continues up to temperatures above 400 C. 3.2 The catalytic activity investigations in propane dehydrogenation The following are the results of tests of the catalytic activity of the studied systems in the dehydrogenation of propane at 600 °C. At temperatures above 600 °C, there is a decrease in propylene yield due to an increase in cracking product yield. Fig. 6 A shows that propane conversion increases with increasing Ga-content and decreases for all samples during the experiment. The specific rate of C3H6 production (Fig. 6B) changes when propane is dehydrogenated on a mixture of C3H8 (15 %):N2 with a change in the space velocity from 2000 h-1 to 200 h-1 for the sample Ga(5 %)/SiO2. In the case of Ga(5 %)/SiO2, there is a strong increase in activity with a decrease in space velocity, i.e. with an increase in contact time. The C3H6 selectivity decreases from ∼98 to ∼80 %. Analysis of propylene production rate dependencies (Fig. 6B) shows that the specific productivity per gram of catalyst is maintained throughout the experiment, except for the dependence obtained at w = 2000 h-1 (Fig. 6B curve 1). Thus, a fresh oxidized surface of Ga/Silica is more active in dehydrogenation than a partially covered with coke. In Fig. 6A shows that with increasing gallium content from 2 to 10 % wt., the activity increases noticeably, while the selectivity for propylene changes little. Thus, the efficiency of the catalyst can be increased by increasing the gallium content. Next, consider the effect of adding CO and CO2 to the reaction mixture on the efficiency of dehydrogenation. Fig. 7 shows the curves of the propylene yield from the operating time of the pre-oxidized Ga(10 %)/Silica for mixtures of different compositions. It can be seen that the addition of CO2 leads to a decrease in the initial yield of propylene and to an increase in the rate of deactivation. In the case of the introduction of CO into the reaction mixture, there is optimal concentration at which the rate of deactivation decreases. At the same time, an excess of CO (curve 5) leads to a decrease in the target product yield. 3.3 Non-stationary investigations The effect of CO and CO2 additives can be seen in their adsorption properties to the catalyst. Using the transient-response method, it is possible to identify the presence of competitive adsorption and the ratio of adsorption constants for different process participants. Fig. 8 -A shows relaxation curves that fixed changes in concentration of C3H6 at quick change (response) of helium to mixture He+C3H6 (response 1: He/He+C3H6) and the quick change of He+CO2 mixture to He+C3H6 (response 2: He+CO2/He+C3H6) at 200 °C in the presence of Ga(10 %)/Silica. It can be seen that the preliminary adsorption of CO2 leads to an increase in the delay in the appearance of propylene. This time is necessary to displace CO2, i.e. propylene competes with carbon dioxide for adsorption on the catalyst surface. Next, the response method shows the effect of the appearance of propylene (Fig. 8-B) and methane (Fig. 8-C) in response to the introduction of propane into the reaction mixture at 600 °C. In the absence of CO2, there is a delay in the appearance of propylene, which is probably associated with the adsorption and oligomerization of the resulting C3H6 up to coke formation (Fig. 8-B, response 1). If the helium flow is changed to a mixture of He+CO2+C3H8, the delay practically disappears (Fig. 8-B, response 2). The result may indicate that the presence of CO2 and their products prevents the adsorption of C3H6. If CO2 is introduced before the introduction of He+CO2+C3H8, then the delay in the appearance of propylene increases (Fig. 8B, response 3). Thus, the presence of carbon dioxide on the surface of the gallium catalyst limits the adsorption of propane. Another effect is found if a change in methane concentration is fixed in similar relaxations (Fig. 8C). It can be seen that in CO2 absence, there is no delay in the appearance of methane when propane is fed into the reactor (Fig. 8C, response 1), obviously due to the relatively low adsorption strength and high stability of methane molecules to transformations. The СО2 addition to the reaction mixture results in a slight delay in the appearance of methane (Fig. 8C, response 2). This delay is increased if the catalyst is treated with carbon dioxide before introducing the mixture He+CO2+C3H8 (Fig. 8C, response 3). Effect of CO addition in the reaction mixture may be due to its reducing and adsorption properties. First, let's analyze the effect of catalyst pretreatment under different conditions on its performance. Fig. 9 shows the effect of oxidative and reductive pretreatment of Ga(10 %)/Silica on the yield of propylene during propane dehydrogenation. It can be seen that pretreatment in oxygen (Fig. 9, curve 2) leads to the fact that the catalyst loses part of the initial activity, compared to the sample pre-treated with nitrogen (Fig. 9, curve 1). Treatment with hydrogen (curve 3 for 650 °C and curve 4 for 700 °C) leads to the fact that the dependence of the C3H6 yield on time acquires a maximum, which increases with increasing pre-treatment temperature, while the deactivation rate noticeably decreases. Thus, reduction treatment increases efficiency of propene production Fig. 10 shows how reduction treatments at different temperatures is decrease the amount of oxidized Ga-silicates on the surface of the support. It can be seen that after treatment at 650 °C (curve 2), a very small part of these particles is reduced, but already at 700 °C the portion of oxidized Ga-containing particles noticeably decreases (curves 3 and 4). At the same time, even after a 3-hour treatment in hydrogen at 750 °C, a significant portion of oxidized particles is detected (curve 5), and the sample is partially sintered. It should be noted that the efficiency of propane dehydrogenation in case of pre-reduced samples decreases with an increase in the carbon monoxide content. These results show that the introduction of CO into the reaction mixture is accompanied by an increase in stability and the propene yield only on pre-oxidized samples (Fig. 7). The positive role of carbon monoxide in this case is associated with the partial reduction of Ga-oxide surface particles. These temperatures are obviously better for ethane dehydrogenation since the propane will be actively cracked. 3.4 The catalytic activity investigations in ethane dehydrogenation The results of catalytic activity studies in ethane dehydrogenation show that the character of catalysts works differently than in propane dehydrogenation at 600 °C. At 700 °C conversion of ethane changes very little during the experiment for Ga(3 %)/SiO2 and Ga(5 %)/SiO2 (Fig. 11 A line 2 and 3). The catalyst Ga(10 %)/SiO2 is less stable (Fig. 11A line 4), in so doing, the increase in specific rate of ethylene production with an increase in temperature is minimal (Fig. 11B line 4). At low Ga-contained catalyst (Ga(2 %)/SiO2), a greater increase in the rate of ethylene production is found with an increase in process temperature (Fig. 11B line 1). In this case, there is not a decrease, but an increase in activity during experiments at 700 °С (Fig. 11A line 1). Fig. 12 shows how the ethylene yield changes with increasing temperature at a low space velocity of 200 h-1 and a high - 1600 h-1. It can be seen that at low load, with increasing temperature, the difference in activity decreases (at 700C, the yield of ethylene for the catalyst Ga(2 %)/SiO2 - 42,3 % и 46,5 % for Ga(10 %)/SiO2). At a high feed rate, the difference in activity increases greatly, the catalyst Ga(10 %)/SiO2 is more than twice as active as Ga(2 %)/SiO2. It can be seen that even with low gallium content, these catalysts exhibit high activity in reducing conditions of ethane dehydrogenation. Using the Ga(2 %)/SiO2 catalyst as an example, the activation energy of ethane dehydrogenation can be evaluated under pseudo-stationary conditions (after more than 200 minutes of work – Fig. 11A) by determining the ethylene production rates at ethane conversions of less than 10 %. Under these conditions, the effect of ethane conversion products on the dehydrogenation rate can be neglected. At similar ethane concentrations, the dehydrogenation rate will be proportional to the rate constant and then –ln(r) = ΔE/RT +const. From the linear dependence -ln (r) = f (1/T), the value of ΔE/R and the value of the activation energy can be easily determined. Table 2 . for comparison, shows data obtained from dehydrogenation of ethane on quartz and catalyst at low conversions. The activation energy obtained on quartz is close to the result given in[43] for non-catalytic dehydrogenation of ethane. The use of a catalyst greatly decreases the activation energy (about 100 kJ/mol.). At high temperatures, in the presence of a reducing agent, Si-O-Ga and Ga-O-Ga bonds can break, leading to diffusion of the metal over the surface of the support and an increase in its dispersion. The effect of the appearance of Ga-containing particles, which after reduction bind weaker to each other and/or the support, can be detected by the TPR-H2 method, if after H2-reduction at 700 °C the samples are oxidized under low temperature 400 °С (Fig. 13 line 2). It can be seen that oxidation under mild conditions contributes to the fact that part of the Ga-contained reduced particles does not turn into a form that is difficult to reduce, probably does not agglomerate into large particles. 4 Discussion and summary If we analyze the results of dehydrogenation of ethane separately from propane, it can be assumed that the high stability of the Ga/SiO2 catalysts is mainly due to a decrease in the surface concentration of adsorbed olefins (and coke) at high temperatures. However, an increase in the stability and activity of propane dehydrogenation (at 600 °C) after preliminary reduction of gallium-containing catalysts at 650–700 °C indicates significant changes in the properties of the catalytic surface with a change in its degree of reduction. On the contrary, additional oxidation of the catalyst and introduction of CO2 into the reaction mixture reduce its efficiency in dehydrogenation of alkanes. Probably, in Ga/SiO2 systems hydrogen transfer in the process is possible both through the formation of Ga-O-H and Ga-H bonds. After catalysts treatment by hydrogen or CO, the content of reduced centers increases and the latter mechanism (hydride) shows itself to a greater extent. On the other hand, it has been shown that particles appear after the reduction of catalysts at high temperatures, which may result from the reductive breaking of Ga-O-Ga and Ga-O-Si bonds and the dispersion of large agglomerates of the active phase. Thus, gallium-based systems deposited on silica have interesting properties that offer prospects for their use as catalysts for the dehydrogenation of light alkanes. These catalysts, prepared by a simple precipitation method using an available cheap support, are highly active and stable in the dehydrogenation of light alkanes, especially at high temperatures. In addition, this type of catalysts is resistant to the presence of small impurities of CO2, CO and H2O, which is extremely important in the organization of production. One of the optimization directions for Ga/SiO2 systems can be considered as increasing the dispersity and stability of the active phase to agglomeration. This will also reduce the temperature of the catalysts effective work and enlarge the possibilities of their use for the dehydrogenation of longer alkanes. coredata.dc:description: The present work is devoted to the studies of Ga/Silica catalysts in the paraffins dehydrogenation of natural gas - propane and ethane to produce valuable products - olefins and hydrogen. The gallium oxide supported on silica gel (2–10 %wt. of Ga) have been studied using XRD, TPR-H2 and STEM/EDS methods, it has been shown that the dispersion of gallium oxide over the silica surface is very effective, the support actively reacts with a gallium salt to form surface particles that are more easily reduced than pure gallium oxide. Under steady and no-stationary state the negative effect of oxidative pre-treatment and the addition of CO2 to the reaction mixture on catalytic activity was detected. On the contrary, pre-treatment of the catalysts in hydrogen (at 650–700 °C) or CO addition to the reaction mixture was accompanied by an increase in their propane dehydrogenation activities and stabilities at 600 °C. In the ethane dehydrogenation conditions (650 to 700 °C) catalysts is effective treated by hydrogen during the experiment. At 700 °C, the Ga/Silica activity may even increase during ethane dehydrogenation. By TPR-H2 it was observed that with an increase in the temperature of pre-treatment of Ga/Silica in hydrogen from 650 to 700 °C, the proportion of oxidized Ga-containing phase significantly decreases.
